STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
July 30, 2024
Jody Schlaufman
Otsego/Crawford/Oscoda DHHS
931 S OTSEGO AVE,
GAYLORD, MI, 49735-1687
RE: License#: CP690201347
Dear Ms. Schlaufman:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed
on June 28, 2024. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective
action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact Samantha Way, Area Manager, at 517-243-9743.
Sincerely,
Douglas Turrill, Licensing Consultant
701 S. Elmwood
Traverse City, MI. 49684
enclosure

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except for
the following:
CPA Rule 400.12502 Program statement
(2) An agency shall give a copy of the
program statement to a youth before
placement in independent living.
Three of three independent living files reviewed did not contain documentation
the agency provided the youth with a copy of the program statement.
CPA Rule 400.12503 Policy and procedures
(3) An agency shall provide a youth in
independent living with a copy of the
agency's policies and procedures required
by this rule.
Three of three independent living files reviewed did not contain documentation
the agency provided the youth with a copy of the program policies and
procedures.

CPA Rule 400.12510 Independent living agreement
(2) The agreement must be signed and dated
by the youth and the social service worker.
The agreement must be reviewed with the
youth at least once every 90 calendar days
and a copy provided to the youth.
Three of three independent living files reviewed did not contain documentation of
an independent living agreement.
CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent
with all the following information before the
placement or replacement of a child:
One of six files reviewed documented the foster parent was provided all
informtion required by the rule however the information was provided after
placement of the child.
CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy
(1) (c) A physical examination for each child as
follows, unless a greater frequency is medically
indicated:
(i) A comprehensive medical examination,
including a behavioral/mental health and trauma
screening, within 30 calendar days from the date
the child entered into an out-of-home placement,
regardless of the date of the last physical
examination.
One of six foster care files reviewed documented that a physical exam was late,
occuring thirty four days after placement.

CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
(2) An agency shall complete written service
plans for each child and parent or parents,
as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the
initial removal and at least once every
90 calendar days thereafter.
One of six foster care files reviewed documented a late updated service plan.
FOM 722-08D Treatment Plans.
Once completed and approved, the caseworker
must obtain signatures from the following
individuals, as applicable.
• Caseworker. • Supervisor. • Parents who are a
member of a participating household. • Youth ages
14 and older. • Foster parents, relative caregivers,
and unrelated court ordered caregivers.
Four of six foster care files reviewed contained one or more treatment plan’s
that were signed more than thirty days from the date of the service plan.
Therefore, the signature pages were not uploaded into the electronic case record
within 30 days of the report date.
REPEAT VIOLATION:
10/04/2023 Interim. CAP approved 11/14/2023.
08/08/2022 Renewal. CAP approved 08/22/2022.
FOM 801-03 Medical Passports
All medical information within the medical passport
must be current and updated at least quarterly to
reflect the child's current and complete health
information.
For children entering foster care, the initial medical
passport must be provided within two weeks of the
child's placement date to the following: • Foster

care provider. • Young adult voluntary foster care
(YAVFC) youth/young adult re-entering foster care.
The actual date the medical passport is provided
must be documented in the electronic case
management record.
One of six foster care files reviewed did not document fourth quarter 2023
medical passport updates.
REPEAT VIOLATION:
10/04/2023 Interim. CAP approved 11/14/2023.
08/08/2022 Renewal. CAP approved 08/22/2022.
FOM 722-06B Family Team Meetings
FTMs must occur within the required time frames
as outlined in the following. Initial Case Plan (ISP) -
within 30 calendar days before the case plan due
date. Updated Case Plan (USP) - within 30 calendar
days before the case plan due date.
One of six foster care files reviewed did not document that FTM’s had occurred
and one of six files documented that an FTM did not occur within the time frame
specified by the policy.
REPEAT VIOLATION:
10/04/2023 Interim. CAP approved 11/14/2023.
0 8/08/2022 Renewal. CAP approved 08/22/2022.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Rule 400.12415 (a) Incident reports. Discussed the requirement that incident
reports are to be submitted to the consultant. Only those incidents named under
the rule are to be submitted.
• DCWL review of Corrective Action Plans (CAP). The agency was informed
that starting January 1, 2024, interim and renewal audit CAP's will be reviewed
with the agency at three months and six months. The assigned Consultant for the

agency will work with the agency in conducting CAP reviews. This process for
special investigation CAP reviews was implemented previously.
• Rule 400.12209 (2) (a) Orientation and Training. The agency was informed
that all the training requirements listed under (2) (a) are required yearly for foster
care workers carrying a caseload as well as for supervisors who may be carrying
a caseload.
V. CONSULTATION
• Consultation was not requested or provided at this time.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plan (CAP) during
this licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows:
The agency submitted an approved corrective action plan on 11/14/23 in response
to three violations established during the interim inspection. The same violations
were cited during the current renewal inspection as second repeat violations, The
current citation for treatment plan signatures remained the same as the interim
inspection as four files had one or more treatment plans lacking signatures or
signatures were late. The violation for medical passports was reduced from
citations in three files in 2023 to one file during the current renewal inspection.
During the 2023 interim inspection the agency had 5 files out of compliance with
the FTM policy. The current renewal inspection established that two files were out
of compliance indicating that the CAP was successful in reducing the number of
incidences.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator Assessment was reviewed. The assessment details
managers meeting monthly to address practices. The quality assurance team
developed plans of action for support of the agency team. The assessment speaks
to the agencies period of rapid growth and development which included the
transition of managers and staff and efforts to maintain compliance during this
period.
Financial Overview
N/A

Staff Interviews
Staff reported feeling supported by their respective supervisors. They also
reported that supervisors are knowledgeable and are available when needed. Staff
reported the agency has a stable supportive team, A Program Manager
interviewed reported that managing all staff can be a challenge, but the agency
has a good team.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency is located in a modern local DHHS office in Gaylord. There is
sufficient office space and the facility is well maintained. CHRI documents were
observed to be secured and a cross shredder is available.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
The CPA Analyst did not find any safety alerts during her visits to the homes.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
7/26/2024
_____________________________________
Douglas Turrill Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
7/30/2024
